close_symbols: Definition/typedef of the struct/type that contains the member EnableTaskPriorities
All assignment sites / functions that write to POSIX_GlobalVars.EnableTaskPriorities (initializers, config setters, init routines)
Any compile-time configuration macros or static initializers that set EnableTaskPriorities to a constant
Any synchronization objects or accessors used to protect/read EnableTaskPriorities (mutexes, atomic accessor functions, e.g. POSIX_GlobalVarsLock or getter/setter functions)
explanation:
1) POSIX_GlobalVars (variable declaration)
   - Required to know the storage, linkage and qualifiers (is the variable declared const/volatile/static?) and whether the controlling expression uses a genuine variable or a compile-time constant. If the variable is a const or defined as a macro alias to a literal, the "if" becomes invariant.

2) Definition/typedef of the struct/type that contains the member EnableTaskPriorities
   - Required to determine the exact type of EnableTaskPriorities (int, bool, enum) and any qualifiers on the member (const/volatile). The type/qualifiers influence whether the expression can be considered invariant by static analysis and whether reads may have side-effects or ordering constraints.

3) All assignment sites / functions that write to POSIX_GlobalVars.EnableTaskPriorities (initializers, configuration setters, init routines)
   - To prove non-invariance you must show there exist runtime writes that can change the member. Listing the functions or locations that assign to EnableTaskPriorities (including initialization code) shows whether the value can change after compilation or startup. If there are no write-sites (or only a single static initializer), the condition may be invariant.

4) Any compile-time configuration macros or static initializers that set EnableTaskPriorities to a constant
   - Some builds may set the field via macros or static initializers to a constant value (e.g., via config headers). Those symbols/definitions are needed to decide if the controlling expression is effectively a compile-time constant and thus violates the MISRA rule.

5) Any synchronization objects or accessor functions used to protect/read EnableTaskPriorities (mutexes, atomic accessor functions, e.g. POSIX_GlobalVarsLock or getter/setter functions)
   - If access is only via guarded/atomic operations or the variable is modified only under lock, the effective semantics for other threads/readers differ. Knowing whether there are atomic operations or locks or accessor functions indicates whether the value can legitimately change at runtime (not an invariant) and whether reads may be optimized away. This affects whether the "if" is considered an invariant controlling expression under MISRA.

Collectively, these symbols let an analyzer determine (a) whether EnableTaskPriorities is a compile-time constant, (b) whether it can change at runtime (and where), and (c) whether concurrency/synchronization affects its mutability — all necessary to decide if the controlling expression is invariant and thus whether the MISRA C rule is violated.
